material.mattext: Across the films we studied (Shutter Island, North by Northwest, Sunset Boulevard, Black Swan, Good Will Hunting, What's Eating Gilbert Grape, Primal Fear, The Hurricane), which psychological construct appeared most consistently as a source of character dysfunction?
Low intelligence
Genetic predisposition
Disrupted or distorted self-representation - whether through delusion, trauma, or external misattribution
Lack of financial resources

Correct!

Across all eight films, identity disturbance emerges as the central theme: - Shutter Island: Andrew creates Teddy identity - North by Northwest: Thornhill assigned Kaplan identity - Sunset Boulevard: Norma's delusional star identity - Black Swan: Nina's fragmented self - Good Will Hunting: Will's defense-constructed identity - Gilbert Grape: Gilbert trapped in caregiver identity - Primal Fear: Aaron/Roy fabricated identity - The Hurricane: Carter's identity defined by false conviction

The correct answer is C.

Across all eight films, identity disturbance emerges as the central theme: - Shutter Island: Andrew creates Teddy identity - North by Northwest: Thornhill assigned Kaplan identity - Sunset Boulevard: Norma's delusional star identity - Black Swan: Nina's fragmented self - Good Will Hunting: Will's defense-constructed identity - Gilbert Grape: Gilbert trapped in caregiver identity - Primal Fear: Aaron/Roy fabricated identity - The Hurricane: Carter's identity defined by false conviction

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Most characters are highly intelligent; intelligence doesn't protect against dysfunction.
  • B: Genetics rarely mentioned; environmental factors predominate in these films.
  • D: Several characters have wealth (Norma, Thornhill); poverty isn't the common factor.

Emotion differentiation research (Kashdan et al., 2015; Kalokerinos et al., 2019) predicts that low differentiators will show ineffective emotion regulation. Which film character best exemplifies this pattern?
Roger Thornhill (competent adaptation to threat)
Sean Maguire (effective therapeutic processing)
Nina Sayers (all regulation attempts increase rather than decrease distress)
Rubin Carter (sustained resistance under pressure)

Correct!

Kalokerinos et al.'s key finding is that low differentiators show REVERSED effects - all regulation strategies increase negative affect. Nina exemplifies this: she tries practice (increases anxiety), perfectionism (increases anxiety), isolation (increases anxiety), seeking help from Thomas (increases anxiety). Every strategy fails because she can't identify what she's actually feeling. Her regulation attempts make her worse, not better.

The correct answer is C.

Kalokerinos et al.'s key finding is that low differentiators show REVERSED effects - all regulation strategies increase negative affect. Nina exemplifies this: she tries practice (increases anxiety), perfectionism (increases anxiety), isolation (increases anxiety), seeking help from Thomas (increases anxiety). Every strategy fails because she can't identify what she's actually feeling. Her regulation attempts make her worse, not better.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Adapts effectively to changing situations; shows regulatory competence.
  • B: Demonstrates differentiated emotional processing and effective regulation.
  • D: Maintains regulation under extreme pressure; shows regulatory success, not failure.

According to the purpose literature (McKnight & Kashdan, 2009; Kashdan et al., 2024), authentic purpose requires self-concordance - alignment between goals and personal values. Which character's arc best demonstrates the DEVELOPMENT of self-concordant purpose?
Norma Desmond (maintained consistent goals)
Will Hunting (moved from externally imposed expectations to self-chosen direction)
Aaron Stampler (achieved his goals effectively)
Teddy Daniels (pursued his mission relentlessly)

Correct!

Will's arc shows purpose DEVELOPMENT. He starts with goals imposed by others (Lambeau's career expectations, his friends' assumptions) and moves toward self-chosen direction (pursuing Skylar, embracing vulnerability). This transformation from external to internal motivation represents the development of self-concordant purpose. He's not just achieving goals; he's choosing goals that align with his authentic values.

The correct answer is B.

Will's arc shows purpose DEVELOPMENT. He starts with goals imposed by others (Lambeau's career expectations, his friends' assumptions) and moves toward self-chosen direction (pursuing Skylar, embracing vulnerability). This transformation from external to internal motivation represents the development of self-concordant purpose. He's not just achieving goals; he's choosing goals that align with his authentic values.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Norma's goals are delusional and don't develop; she maintains static dysfunction.
  • C: Aaron's goals are manipulative; effectiveness isn't the same as self-concordance.
  • D: Teddy pursues delusion, not authentic purpose; his mission is a defensive construct.

Shermer (2002) and Boudry & Braeckman (2012) both emphasize that intelligent people can construct sophisticated defenses for irrational beliefs. Which film most explicitly dramatizes this "smart person's folly"?
What's Eating Gilbert Grape
The Hurricane
Shutter Island (Andrew constructs an elaborate, internally consistent delusional system)
North by Northwest

Correct!

Shutter Island most explicitly shows intelligent rationalization of irrational belief. Andrew is clearly intelligent - he constructs an elaborate, internally consistent delusional system complete with conspiracy theories, fake investigations, and interpretive frameworks. Every piece of contradictory evidence is reinterpreted to support the delusion. This is Shermer's "smart person's folly" dramatized: intelligence creating better defenses, not better truth-detection.

The correct answer is C.

Shutter Island most explicitly shows intelligent rationalization of irrational belief. Andrew is clearly intelligent - he constructs an elaborate, internally consistent delusional system complete with conspiracy theories, fake investigations, and interpretive frameworks. Every piece of contradictory evidence is reinterpreted to support the delusion. This is Shermer's "smart person's folly" dramatized: intelligence creating better defenses, not better truth-detection.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Characters aren't particularly sophisticated in their belief defenses.
  • B: Carter maintains TRUE beliefs; this isn't about defending irrationality.
  • D: Thornhill is confused by others' beliefs, not constructing elaborate defenses of his own.

The course examined six governing areas of inquiry: BELIEF, PURPOSE, MOTIVATION, UNCERTAINTY, DISCOMFORT, and EMOTION. According to the psychological research we reviewed, how do these areas relate to each other?
They are independent, modular systems with no interaction
They form a strict hierarchy with belief at the top
They are reducible to a single underlying construct
They interact dynamically - uncertainty affects belief, emotion affects motivation, purpose organizes the others - forming an integrated psychological system

Correct!

The course emphasized interconnection among all six constructs: - Uncertainty strengthens certain beliefs (Boudry & Braeckman) - Emotion differentiation affects regulation and motivation (Kashdan et al.) - Purpose organizes behavior and provides meaning (McKnight & Kashdan) - Discomfort motivates belief change or defense - Motivation is shaped by emotional states These aren't separate modules but an integrated system where changes in one area ripple through others.

The correct answer is D.

The course emphasized interconnection among all six constructs: - Uncertainty strengthens certain beliefs (Boudry & Braeckman) - Emotion differentiation affects regulation and motivation (Kashdan et al.) - Purpose organizes behavior and provides meaning (McKnight & Kashdan) - Discomfort motivates belief change or defense - Motivation is shaped by emotional states These aren't separate modules but an integrated system where changes in one area ripple through others.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Contradicts extensive evidence for interconnection.
  • B: No evidence for a single top construct; relationships are bidirectional.
  • C: The constructs are related but meaningfully distinct.
